coredata.dc:title: An advanced plasmonic photocatalyst containing silver(0) single atoms for selective borylation of aryl iodides
coredata.dc:creator: Cui, Enxin
Li, Haibin
Zhang, Chen
Qiao, Dan
Gawande, Manoj B.
Tung, Chen-Ho
Wang, Yifeng
coredata.dc:description: A conventional plasmonic Ag-AgCl photocatalyst consists of Ag nanoparticles (AgNPs) and AgCl. Here, we converted a small amount of Ag+ on the surfaces of AgCl particles into single-atom Ag(0) (SAAg). SAAg was characterized with high-angle annular dark field aberration corrected (HAADF AC)-STEM and quantified with electron spin resonance (ESR). The obtained AgEG/Mg(OH)2 material was efficient and afforded excellent selectivity control between hydrodehalogenation and deiodination-borylation under visible light irradiation. SAAg acted as the 1e−-reducing site of the photocatalyst and its loading is linearly correlated with the initial reaction rate. While the quantity of SAAg was only 6.0 × 10–8 mol g−1, the TOF of SAAg reached 1.4 × 104 h−1. The oxidation state of SAAg retained 0 in both the resting and the working states. This study suggests SAAg may be an effective cocatalyst in general for reductive dehalogenation of organic halides.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Single atom catalysis
Visible light
Dehalogenation
Organic halide
Plasmonic photocatalysts

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (A) The size distribution of the AgNPs of the materials. (B) The diffuse-reflectance UV–vis spectra.

(A) Procedure of removal of Ag(I) and (B) XPS evidence for the complete removal of Ag(I). (C) Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra of the prepared materials. (D) TEM image of Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2. (D) HR-TEM image and (E) the element mapping analysis of Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2. (F) High-angle annular dark field aberration corrected (HAADF AC)-STEM image of Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2 showing the coexistence of SAAg, subnanometer Ag clusters and AgNPs.

The outcome of the borylation reactions using AgEG/Mg(OH)2 photocatalysis. The percentage values are isolated yields. Conditions for B and C: AgEG/Mg(OH)2, 20 mg; substrate, 20 mg; boron source, 3 eq; MeCN, 2.0 mL; 425 ± 7 nm LED; 1 atm N2.

(A) ESR spectra of the AgEG/Mg(OH)2 samples obtained by solvothermal treatment of the AgCl/Mg(OH)2 composites in the EG-H2O mixtures for different time. (B) The kinetics for the borylation of 1 using the above materials. ESR data in Fig. S11 demonstrate that the loading of SAAg kept almost constant in the early stage of the photocatalytic reaction (e.g., the first 3 h). (C) Linear correlation between the reaction rate and the loading of SAAg (R2 = 0.974). The point at (0,0) was obtained with AgPR/Mg(OH)2.

The kinetics for the borylation of 1 using the three materials with the same loading of SAAg and different loadings of AgNPs: (A) the temporal conversion of 1 and (B) the rate of conversion as a function of the loading of AgNPs.

The rational structures SAAg on the low-index lattice planes of AgCl. Color scheme: blue, SAAg; green, Cl− anions; purple, Ag+. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
Schematic presentation of the synthesis of the materials.
The possible working states of SAAg in reduction of 1.

head.ce:title: An advanced plasmonic photocatalyst containing silver(0) single atoms for selective borylation of aryl iodides

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A conventional plasmonic Ag-AgCl photocatalyst consists of Ag nanoparticles (AgNPs) and AgCl. Here, we converted a small amount of Ag+ on the surfaces of AgCl particles into single-atom Ag(0) (SAAg). SAAg was characterized with high-angle annular dark field aberration corrected (HAADF AC)-STEM and quantified with electron spin resonance (ESR). The obtained AgEG/Mg(OH)2 material was efficient and afforded excellent selectivity control between hydrodehalogenation and deiodination-borylation under visible light irradiation. SAAg acted as the 1e−-reducing site of the photocatalyst and its loading is linearly correlated with the initial reaction rate. While the quantity of SAAg was only 6.0 × 10–8 mol g−1, the TOF of SAAg reached 1.4 × 104 h−1. The oxidation state of SAAg retained 0 in both the resting and the working states. This study suggests SAAg may be an effective cocatalyst in general for reductive dehalogenation of organic halides.

ce:section.ce:para: Arylboronates are centrally important building blocks and synthetic precursors in organic chemistry [1,2]. For their synthesis, the borylation of aryl halides is one of the most economic routes studied so far [1,2]. Recently, impressive efforts have been made by Fu [3], Marder [4,5], Jiao [6] and others [7–9] using transition metal-coordination complexes [3–5,9] or π-conjugated molecules [6–8] as the photocatalysts for light-driven processes which can be practicable alternatives to the transition metal catalysis or alkoxide-induced radical processes in borylation of halides [1,2,10]. As these systems are homogeneous thus the catalyst separation and reuse are difficult [11]. By contrast, heterogeneous photocatalysts are generally considered cheap, recyclable and environmentally benign [12]. Some recyclable photocatalysts for synthesis of arylboronates by borylation of aromatic C-H moieties have been fabricated by decorating the molecular photocatalysts on supports [13–16] or imbedding them in metal-organic frameworks [17–23]. A few studies also showed that the visible light-responsive semiconductors like Cu2O, ZnS, CdS and g-C3N4 could photocatalyze aromatic halides for hydrodehalogenation reactions with Pd, Pt or Au nanoparticles as the cocatalysts [12,24–27]. However, visible light-responsive heterogeneous photocatalysts for borylation of aromatic halides, a trait of materials chemistry and solar synthesis, have not been explored.

The plasmonic Ag(0)-AgX (X = Cl, Br, I) hybrids have been extensively studied as an important class of visible light responsive inorganic materials due to their ready availability and high efficiency of visible light absorption [28–39]. Structurally, an Ag(0)-AgX hybrid consists of both the plasmonic Ag(0) nanoparticles (AgNPs) and the semiconducting AgX particles between which a Schottky junction exists at the interface [40]. To increase their photocatalytic activities, extensive efforts have been made on controlling NPs’ morphology [41], halide type [28,42,43] and AgNPs-AgX interfacial property [44]. These strategies greatly increase the efficiencies of visible light absorption and charge separation, thereby boost the formation of oxidizing species such as holes,·OH radicals and superoxide during the aerobic photocatalytic reactions, and ultimately promote the oxidation applications such as antimicrobial and environmental remediation photocatalysis [31,34,42–46]. However, using of Ag(0)-AgX materials in hydrodehalogenation or borylation of organic halides remains elusive. This is likely because Ag+ ions competes with C-X bonds for the photogenerated electrons since reduction of a C-X bond occurs at very negative potentials (e.g., for p-iodoanisole Ere = −1.2 V vs SCE in MeCN [47,48]) and the AgX surfaces lack reducing sites. Notably, the aforementioned strategies for modification of Ag(0)-AgX hybrids [28,41–43] are not competent for enhancing the reducing abilities of them.

We speculated that to enable the plasmonic Ag(0)-AgX hybrids in reductive activation of aryl halides for borylation reactions, certain active centers must be installed on the surfaces of the AgX grains. Hence, we envisaged modifying the Ag(0)-AgX hybrids by reducing a portion of the surface Ag+ of AgX into SAAg. As such, the formed SAAg could contact the AgX surfaces intimately with little Schottky barrier. Due to the high surface energy, SAAg should also be able to interact strongly with the C-X bonds of organic halides, leading the conduction band (CB) electrons of AgX to be transferred smoothly to the substrate to initiate the reduction reactions. Although Tang, Zou, Wang and others have loaded atomically dispersed silver on various supports and realized outstanding activities in NO reduction [49], hydrogen evolution [50] and CO2 reduction [51], the oxidation state of the effective silver species in their catalysts, i.e., + 1, is different from the current study.

Here, we prepared an SAAg-containing plasmonic AgEG/Mg(OH)2 photocatalyst which showed unprecedented activities of the Ag(0)-AgX hybrids in the borylation of aryl iodides. While the quantity of SAAg, ca. 6.0 × 10–8 mol g−1, is negligible to the mass content of AgNPs (5.7 × 10–5: 1), SAAg played the key role in the reductive activation of aryl iodides with a very large TOF value of 1.4 × 104 h−1. This study not only develops a visible light-driven, heterogeneous and Pd-free photocatalyst for dehalogenation-borylation, but also may provide a new strategy of using metal(0) single atoms for improving the reduction capability of the other photocatalysts.

AgNO3 (analytical grade, 99%) was purchased from Xiya Reagent Ltd. MgCl2.6H2O was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Methyl orange (MO) was obtained from J&K Scientific. Nafion 117 solution (~5% in a mixture of lower aliphatic alcohols and water) was obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. The commercially available iodides and bisphenol A (BPA) were obtained from Bokachem (purity > 98%). The commercially unavailable iodides were prepared following the previous procedures [52]. Bis(pinacolato) diboron (B2pin2) was purchased from Ark Pharm, Inc. The other boron sources were purchased from Energy Chemical. Dichloromethane and acetonitrile solvents were of analytical grade and distilled over calcium hydride before use. The other solvents were dried with molecular sieve before use. The acids, bases and the other salts used in this study were obtained from commercial sources. Deionized water (18.2 MΩ cm) was used for the preparation of the materials.

To 16 mL of water containing 1.218 g of MgCl2.6H2O was added 1.0 M NaOH under vigorous stirring until pH reached 12. The suspension was then transferred to an autoclave and maintained 200 °C for 16 h. Then, 5.0 mL of 0.10 M AgNO3 was added under vigorous stirring. AgCl/Mg(OH)2 formed as the precipitate. Next, 10 mL of ethylene glycol was added, and the suspension was maintained 200 °C for 8 h. The dark brown precipitate was isolated by centrifugation, washed with deionized water for 5 times, dried at 60 °C for 24 h, and stored in the dark before use. In the following, all the materials were isolated and stored following this procedure.

0.50 g of the as-prepared AgEG/Mg(OH)2 and 0.10 mL of methanol were added to 50 mL of water in a Pyrex flask. The flask was then sealed with a rubber stopper and purged with high-purity N2 (99.999%) for 10 min. Then the suspension was irradiated with UV light (100 W 395 nm LED) under stirring for different time (e.g., 10 min) by which AgCl was partially reduced to AgNPs. According to our measurements, this treatment increased the loading of AgNPs but did not change the loading of SAAg.
Different from the procedure of AgEG/Mg(OH)2, 5 mL of methanol was used instead of EG in the preparation of AgHT/Mg(OH)2. Also, the solvothermal reaction time was 8 h.

5 mL of methanol was added to the above dispersion of AgCl/Mg(OH)2. The dispersion was purged with high-purity N2 for 10 min. Next, the suspension was irradiated with UV light (100 W 395 nm LED) under stirring for 4 h by which AgCl was partially reduced to AgNPs.

200 mg of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 was soaked twice in 50 mL of 5.0 M aqueous ammonia at room temperature for 12 h. Afterwards, the insoluble residue was filtered, washed five times with water and air-dried before use.

HAADF AC-STEM was performed on a JEOL JEM–ARM 200 F TEM operating at 200 kV equipped with a spherical aberration corrector (CEOS Gmbh). Low resolution TEM was done using a JEOL JEM–1011 instrument operating at 100 kV. High resolution TEM analysis was performed on the JEM-2010 F instrument. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffraction instrument. UV–vis spectra were measured using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV-2550, Shimadzu, Japan). Single crystal X-ray diffraction data (SCXRD) were collected using a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Electron spin resonance (ESR) was performed on a JOEL X320 instrument at room temperature with Mn-marker as the external reference. NMR was recorded using the Bruker 500 MHz Fourier transform NMR spectrometer in 5 mm NMR tubes. Gas chromatography (GC) was conducted with a GC-7900 instrument (Techcomp, China) equipped with an FID detector and a capillary column (TM-5, 60 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 µm). Gas chromatography-mass spectroscopy (GC-MS) measurements were conducted using Shimadzu QP2010 SE system equipped with a capillary column (HP-5, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 µm). Column chromatography for purification of the organic compounds was performed using 200–300 mesh silica according to standard techniques. The BET surface area values using N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm were measured with Kubo X1000 Aperture specific surface area analyzer (Builder, China). Atomic force microscopic (AFM) images were acquired on a Dimension Icon Scanning Probe Microscope (Veeco Instruments Inc). The photoluminescence (PL) measurements were performed on a high efficiency integrated fluorescence spectrometer (Horiba FluoroMax-4) equipped with a 150 W Xenon lamp as the excitation source with excitation at 374 nm. Time-resolved fluorescence decay spectra were recorded using a time correlated singleproton counting system (FS5 Spectrofluorometer, Edinburgh Instruments) equipped with a 380 nm picosecond pulsed diode laser (EPLED-380) as the excitation source. Electrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Science Technology Corp., Ltd).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Method for the quantification of SAAg, AgCl and Ag(0)
ce:section.ce:para: The loading of SAAg was quantified using solid-state ESR with TEMPO as the spin standard. The details were reported previously [52].

The content of Ag(0) was measured as follows. First, 100 mg of a solid sample was suspended in 20 mL of 5.0 M aqueous ammonia to dissolve AgCl. After soaking for ca. 2 h, the dispersion was centrifuged. After disposing the supernatant, the precipitate was washed with water for five times. The precipitate was then soaked in 2.0 mL of 1.0 M nitric acid for 24 h in the dark to fully dissolve Ag(0). AgI remained insoluble and was removed by filtration. The resultant solution was diluted quantitatively to 100 mL. The concentrations of Ag+ was determined by the Volhard method, using ferric ammonium sulfate as the indicator and 0.03 M ammonium thiocyanate standard solution as the titration solution. Finally, the content of Ag(0) of the solid material could be calculated.

The content of AgCl was measured as follows. First, 100 mg of a solid sample was suspended in 5.0 mL of 1.0 M nitric acid to dissolve both Ag(0) and Mg(OH)2. The residue solid, i.e., AgCl, was recycled by centrifugation and washed with deionized water, and finally dried at 60 °C for 24 h. The weight of AgCl was used to calculate the content of AgCl.

Crystals of 10a appropriate for SCXRD were obtained by recrystallization in ethanol. SCXRD was performed on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) at 173 K. Structure solution and refinement were performed using Olex2 imbedded with the ShelX package. Hydrogen atoms were added theoretically. Crystallographic data for 10a: formula, C28H38B2O8; MW = 524.2 g mol−1; T = 172.99(10) K; crystal system, monoclinic; space group, P21/c; a = 24.7876(7) Å, b = 6.5903(2) Å, c = 18.3239(5) Å; α = 90°, β = 109.334(3) °, δ = 90°; V = 2824.54(15) Å3; Z = 4; ρ cald = 1.233 g cm−3; μ = 0.716 mm−1; F(000) = 1120.0; 2θmax = 152.616; 16925 reflections; 5549 independent reflections (Rint = 0.0522); R1 = 0.0452; wR 2 = 0.1369 for all reflections; 0 restraints; GOOF = 1.061 for all reflections; max/min residual electron density, 0.28/− 0.20 e Å−3.

Transient photocurrent response was measured using a standard three-electrode cell. For preparation of the working electrode, a piece of fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass was washed sequentially with ethanol, isopropanol and acetone, and then dried at 60 °C. 20 mg of catalyst and 30 μL of Nafion solution were dispersed in 1 mL of ethanol under sonication. The above dispersion (50 μL) was dropped onto a 0.5 × 3 cm2 FTO glass electrode and dried naturally under ambient conditions. The conditions for the photocurrent measurements were: Pt wire counter electrode, Ag/AgCl reference electrode and Na2SO4 (0.5 M dissolved in 1:9 v/v methanol-water solution) as the electrolyte.

The electrode was prepared following the protocol as above. A 0.1 M K3[Fe(CN)6] and K4Fe(CN)6 solution was used as the electrolyte. EIS was carried out in the frequency range of 0.01–106 Hz with an amplitude of 0.2 V at the open circuit potential by the AC impedance method.

The single–wavelength LED lamps were assembled using plant grow light LED chips. The spectra of the LED lamps were reported previously [52]. The 425 ± 7 nm LED was used to perform all the reactions unless otherwise specified. Taking the borylation of 1 with AgEG/Mg(OH)2 as the example. 20 mg of 1, 3 eq of B2pin2 and 20 mg of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 were dispersed in 2.0 mL of dry MeCN in a pyrex vial. For all reactions, n-dodecane was added as an internal standard of GC as necessary. The vial was sealed with a rubber stopper and purged with high-purity N2 for 10 min. Then, the suspension was irradiated from the side at room temperature. After every certain time, ca. 1.0 μL of the solution was withdrawn and analyzed with GC or GC-MS to examine the products and the reaction kinetics. After complete conversion of 1, the dispersion was filtered with celite to remove catalyst and then the filtrate was concentrated to give a residue which was purified by column chromatography for further analysis.

The degradation reactions were performed under aerobic conditions at room temperature.[43] A Pyrex vial (25 mL) was used for the reactions. To this vial was added 40 mg of the catalyst and 20 mL of the MO solution (1 × 10−5 mol L−1). For the degradation of BPA, the initial concentration was 1 × 10−4 M. The dispersion was stirred for 20 min in the dark to establish adsorption/desorption equilibrium. Then the dispersion was irradiated from the side with a Xenon lamp which was equipped with a 400 nm longpass filter (model CEL-HXF 300; Beijing China Education Aulight Co., Ltd; 300 W). After every certain time, 2.0 mL of the solution was taken out. After filtration, the concentration was quantified by UV–vis spectroscopy.

Scheme 1 illustrates the preparation of the materials. A white AgCl/Mg(OH)2 composite was prepared by precipitation of aqueous AgNO3 with chloride in the presence of the sheet-like Mg(OH)2 (Fig. S1). It was then treated in a 38 vol% ethylene glycol (EG)-H2O solution at 200 °C for 8 h to furnish the SAAg-containing AgEG/Mg(OH)2. Alternatively, AgCl/Mg(OH)2 was dispersed in a methanol-water mixture, and then hydrothermally treated to provide AgHT/Mg(OH)2 or photolyzed with UV to provide AgPR/Mg(OH)2. Both AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and AgPR/Mg(OH)2 are free of SAAg as shown later.

In the TEM and SEM images of AgEG/Mg(OH)2, the grains of AgNPs and AgCl located on the sheets of Mg(OH)2 are discernible (Figs. S3–S5), consistent with the SPR absorption. As Ag(I) could obscure the visualization of AgNPs and especially SAAg, AgEG/Mg(OH)2 was soaked in aqueous ammonia to remove Ag(I) thoroughly ( Fig. 2A), leading to the fixation of both AgNPs and SAAg onto the surfaces of Mg(OH)2 sheets (the resultant sample is denoted as Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2). The absence of Ag(I) in Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2 was verified by XPS (Fig. 2B) and UV–vis measurements [53]. Consistently, the XRD pattern in Fig. S1 shows Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2 consists of only metallic silver and Mg(OH)2.

The 4d105s1 electronic configuration and the paramagnetic property of an Ag atom inspire us to use ESR as a rapid diagnostic tool for the analysis of SAAg in prior to TEM imaging [52]. While both AgEG/Mg(OH)2 and Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2 exhibit the same g = 2.003 peak (ΔH1/2 ≈ 0.007), both AgPR/Mg(OH)2 and AgHT/Mg(OH)2 are ESR silent (Fig. 2C). It was also revealed that the g = 2.003 peak of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 retained after the treatment of the sample with acid (1.0 M HCl), base (1.0 M NaOH), organic radical quencher (10 mM TEMPO) or reducing agent (0.10 M NaBH4). Hence, it should not be assigned as Ag+, organic residue or Mg(OH)2, but should be assigned as SAAg similar to our previous report [52]. The loading of SAAg could be quantified by ESR using TEMPO as the spin standard [52] and the values are 6.0 and 1.2 × 10–8 mol g−1 for AgEG/Mg(OH)2 and Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2, respectively (Table 1). The mass ratio of SAAg to AgNPs is 5.7 × 10–5: 1 for AgEG/Mg(OH)2. Further, since the average size of AgNPs is found to be 17 nm, the molar loading of AgNPs of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 is estimated to be 7.0 × 10–9 mol g−1. Hence, the molar ratio of SAAg and AgNPs of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 is ca. 8.6: 1.

Figs. S3-S6 display the low-resolution TEM, SEM and high-resolution (HR)-TEM images of AgEG/Mg(OH)2, AgPR/Mg(OH)2, AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2. However, only AgNPs could be seen due to the inadequate resolution of these techniques, while the subnanometer species like SAAg could not be discernable. Hence, it appeared that AgEG/Mg(OH)2, AgPR/Mg(OH)2 and AgHT/Mg(OH)2 were quite similar. For sample Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2, many AgNPs of size ranging 3–150 nm were observed, consistent with that of AgEG/Mg(OH)2, while most of the Mg(OH)2 sheets free of AgNPs appeared “empty”. By contrast, using the mapping function of the HR-TEM (Fig. 2D,E), some distributions of Ag(0) were unequivocally detected in the empty regions (Fig. 2E), showing that there existed Ag(0) species too tiny to be visualized directly by using HR-TEM. As Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2 did not contain Ag(I), these Ag(0) species were assigned as the atomically dispersed silver. To visualize these species, the subångstrom-resolution HAADF AC-STEM was adopted to analyze Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2. The images revealed that there were indeed randomly dispersed dots of ca. 0.3 nm beyond the AgNPs which were assigned as SAAg (Fig. 2F, S6 and S7). Meanwhile, small aggregates of Ag atoms, namely, Ag(0)N clusters (N = 2–10), were very rarely seen.

To examine the activities of SAAg in photocatalysis, we first compared the activities of AgEG/Mg(OH)2, AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and AgPR/Mg(OH)2 in aerobic photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants in water under visible light irradiation, a common application of the analogous materials [37–39,43,54]. Methyl orange and bisphenol A were chosen as the models of dye pollutants and ecotoxic phenols, respectively. It was observed that all three plasmonic materials effectively photocatalyzed the degradation (Fig. S8). The degradation rate by AgEG/Mg(OH)2 was slightly larger than those by AgPR/Mg(OH)2 and AgHT/Mg(OH)2. The ESR measurements and the quenching experiments imply·OH radicals are directly involved (Fig. S8), showing the degradation is indeed an oxidation process [37–39,43,54]. We measured PL spectra, PL lifetime, photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectra of the three materials (Fig. S9). While the PL spectra were nearly identical, the PL lifetime of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 was slightly longer than the other two. Meanwhile, AgEG/Mg(OH)2 exhibited slightly stronger photocurrent response and larger ionic conductivity than both AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and AgPR/Mg(OH)2. Thus, the slightly enhanced photocatalytic degradation activity of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 may be attributed to the enhanced charge separation and migration. Nonetheless, SAAg possesses little effects in the photocatalytic oxidation activities of AgEG/Mg(OH)2.

When AgEG/Mg(OH)2 was employed for the borylation of 4-iodoanisole (1) with B2pin2 under visible light irradiation ( Fig. 3A), 1 was rapidly converted and 4-methoxyphenyl boronate ester (1a) was obtained almost quantitatively (Fig. 3B,C). For example, the isolated yields of 1a reached 96%, 95% and 91% using 425 ± 7 nm light, > 400 nm visible light and sunlight, respectively (Table S1). We examined the effects of irradiation wavelength on the outcome and found out that with 450 nm irradiation conversion of 1 could reach 100% but the selectivity of 1a was only 53% while with longer wavelengths the reaction could not occur (Table S1). Control experiments showed that both AgEG/Mg(OH)2 and light were essential for initiating the conversion of 1 (Table S1). In the catalyst recycling experiments, AgEG/Mg(OH)2 remained highly active and selective for the first two runs (conversion = 100% and yield of 1a > 91%), and became unstable in the third run (conversion = 41% and yield of 1a = 32%; Fig. S10). The overall turnover number (TON), defined as the amount of converted 1 divided by the total amount of Ag(0), reached nearly 12. Hence, AgEG/Mg(OH)2 is truly a photocatalyst that harvests visible light for borylation of 1. By contrast, both AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and AgPR/Mg(OH)2 showed no activity initially. Notably, this photocatalytic activity in borylation of 1 unique for AgEG/Mg(OH)2 must not be explained by the slightly enhanced charge separation/migration efficiency of AgEG/Mg(OH)2, but is best attributed to the existence of SAAg. After the induction periods, both AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and AgPR/Mg(OH)2 initiated the conversion of 1 and formation of 1a. However, they afforded both low conversions and low yields, e.g., < 26% and < 12%, respectively. The ESR measurements indicated that SAAg slowly formed during the induction periods (Fig. S11). The loadings of SAAg of the used AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and AgPR/Mg(OH)2 materials were lower than that of fresh AgEG/Mg(OH)2, consistent with the key role of SAAg in the borylation reaction as shown later.

Based on the success of borylation of 1, we then examined the scope of the current protocol. Strikingly, a gram-scale reaction conducted under sunlight irradiation afforded 100% conversion of 1 and 73% yield of 1a within 35 h, demonstrating the high potential of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 in harvesting sunlight and batch synthesis ( Fig. 4A). Nonetheless, AgEG/Mg(OH)2 could be used in general for synthesis of various organic borates from the corresponding iodides, including aryl and vinyl iodides (Fig. 4B). The other boron sources like symmetrical diborons and silylborane worked well to produce the corresponding borates in good yields (Fig. 4C). It was also found out that CsF could be used to control the product selectivity of the current method [52]. With added CsF, the same procedure afforded solely the hydrodeiodination product of all the organic iodides listed in Fig. 4B. For example, anisole was almost quantitatively obtained by the hydrodeiodination of 1 (yield of 1b = 99%; Table S1). Therefore, the current photocatalytic system, as the first heterogeneous one and using an advanced plasmonic photocatalyst, could serve as an efficient borylation tool alternative to the current homogeneous systems [1–10], with the ability to selectively afford the corresponding organic boronates and hydrodehalogenation products.

To examine the actual role of SAAg in the borylation of 1, the effects of SAAg loading on initial reaction rate was investigated. To control the loadings of SAAg, a set of AgCl/Mg(OH)2 composites were solvothermally treated in the EG-H2O mixtures for different time ( Fig. 5A). When the resultant samples were used for the photocatalytic borylation of 1, constant rates in the early stages were observed (Fig. 5B) and importantly, a linear correlation between the initial reaction rate and the loading of SAAg was revealed (Fig. 5C). Note that the contents of Ag(0) of the obtained materials were also different. However, the results shown immediately later demonstrate that the content of Ag(0) (mainly in the form of AgNPs) did not affect the initial reaction kinetics. Therefore, SAAg must be the catalytically active centers during the selective borylation of 1. Also, since AgPR/Mg(OH)2 and AgHT/Mg(OH)2 contain only AgNPs and showed no activity in the initial reactions, the adatoms on the surfaces of AgNPs must not be the active centers of deiodination. Notably, the mass content of SAAg of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 is very small (6.0 × 10–8 mol g−1) and the TOF of SAAg is calculated to be 1.4 × 104 h−1, the largest so far as compared to the previous reports on catalysis using atomically dispersed silver (Table S2).

When C6F5I was used as the reactant, the deiodination-dimerization product was detected (Fig. S12). Meanwhile, an intramolecular deiodination-cyclization product of 2-iodo-4-methoxy-1-(prop-2-yn-1-yloxy)benzene was successfully isolated in the photocatalytic reaction with AgEG/Mg(OH)2. Both evidences firmly corroborate the radical mechanism for the photocatalytic deiodination of 1 (recall Fig. 3C) [52]. Also, both the conversion of 1 and the yield of 1a could increase by over 50% after turning off the lamp (Fig. S12), indicating borylation of 1 follows the radical chain propagation mechanism. The radical mechanism not only refutes the oxidative addition/reductive elimination mechanism typical for the Miyaura-type borylation reactions [55,56], but also indicates that the photocatalytic deiodination of 1 must be initiated by 1e–-reduction [1,2,10,57], with SAAg as the reduction site.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Roles of AgNPs, AgCl and Mg(OH)2
ce:section.ce:para: Both the semiconducting AgCl (Eg = 3.26 eV [58]) and the atomically dispersed SAAg (excitation energy of transition from 4d105 s1 to 4d95 s2 is 3.97 eV [59]) should not absorb visible light. Thus, the visible light absorption of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 should be mainly attributed to the SPR [45] of metallic AgNPs in the hybrid material [42,44]. To check the roles of AgNPs in the borylation of 1, we prepared three samples with constant loading of SAAg and varying loadings of AgNPs. This was achieved by photolysis of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 in an aqueous dispersion with added methanol. Notably, the loading of SAAg maintained as indicated by ESR while that of AgNPs increased during photolysis. Fig. 6 depicts the kinetics of borylation of 1 with such materials. While constant rates of conversion of 1 were observed, the rates did not vary much with the mass loading of AgNPs. This confirms that SAAg was the catalytic center or co-catalyst and also implies that light absorption was not the bottleneck of the yield of the deiodination reaction in the current study.

To probe the roles of AgCl, the performance of Ag(0)/Mg(OH)2 was investigated. However, it was thoroughly inert in the conversion of 1 (Table S1), indicating AgCl is essential for the activity of borylation of 1. An et al. previously found that the interfaces between AgNPs and AgCl particles were important to the efficiency of charge separation and transport of the AgNPs-AgCl hybrid [44]. Consistently, the role of AgCl should be quite similar herein. Replacing Mg(OH)2 by Zn(OH)2 or Al2O3, the resultant AgEG/Zn(OH)2 and AgEG/Al2O3 were both competent photocatalysts for the borylation of 1, despite the slight lower selectivities (Table S1). Hence, Mg(OH)2 is not a privileged support. However, it was found out that if no support was used the loading of SAAg was lower and the outcome was poorer. In detail, when a pristine AgCl sample was treated in the EG-H2O system at 200 °C (see Scheme 1), with optimized reaction time the loading of SAAg could reach a maxima of ca. 2.0 × 10–8 mol g−1. Meanwhile, the resultant Ag(0)-AgCl sample afforded 100% conversion of 1 and 60% selectivity of 1a (Table S1). Hence, a support not only reduces the usage of silver, but also benefits the formation of SAAg presumably because it increases the dispersity of the parental AgCl particles.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Discussion on the structure and activity of SAAg
ce:section.ce:para: By the treatment of AgCl/Mg(OH)2 in EG/H2O at 200 °C, AgEG/Mg(OH)2 which consisted of 6.0 × 10−8 mol g−1 SAAg (6.5 ppm) and 11.4 wt% Ag(0) was prepared. According to the crystal growth theories [60,61], Ag+ is firstly reduced to SAAg which then undergoes nucleation and crystal growth to form AgNPs. In the preparation of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 and AgHT/Mg(OH)2, EG and methanol acted as the reductants of Ag+. Since Ag+-salts are light-sensitive, light triggers the reduction of Ag+ under many circumstances like the preparation of AgPR/Mg(OH)2 herein. However, it is known that metal(0) single atoms are highly unstable due to the high activity and are transient species. Instead, the materials containing metal(0) single atoms could be synthesized using special supports that provided strong covalent metal-support interaction (CMSI) to stabilize the metal(0) singles atoms [62]. Wei et al. also prepared SAAg by photolysis of a frozen AgNO3 solution [63]. In these cases the metal(0) single atoms were immobilized so that the nucleation of them was prohibited. Since both AgHT/Mg(OH)2 and AgPR/Mg(OH)2 did not consist of SAAg, SAAg must immediately undergo nucleation once formed. Liu et al. reported that single atom Pd(0) could be loaded on TiO2 surfaces with the assistance of EG under light irradiation. There, EG radicals bonded on the TiO2 surfaces served to facilitate the removal of Cl– on Pd and stabilized individual Pd atoms by forming Pd–O bonds [64]. Here, formation of SAAg could only occur in the presence of EG at 200 °C. Hence, we consider EG may also serve to stabilize individual Ag atoms during the solvothermal treatment of AgCl/Mg(OH)2 following the mechanism of Liu et al. [64] Meanwhile, different from TiO2, since Ag+ is a soft acid EG should associate with the surfaces of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 very weakly and is readily removed by washing with water. Consistently, IR spectra revealed that no EG remained in AgEG/Mg(OH)2 (recall Fig. S2).

It is difficult to obtain the precise environment of SAAg in AgEG/Mg(OH)2 due to the presence of Ag+. However, since (1) both SAAg and AgNPs are formed in situ by partial reduction of AgCl on Mg(OH)2 by EG [44], (2) Mg(OH)2 is not essential for the stabilization of SAAg as SAAg could also be prepared from pristine AgCl and (3) EG was thoroughly removed from the as-prepared AgEG/Mg(OH)2, both SAAg and AgNPs should contact intimately with surfaces of the parental AgCl grains, just like the numerous reports on AgNPs-AgX hybrids prepared using the analogous protocols [43,44,54]. The single, symmetrical and narrow ESR peak of SAAg suggests the unpaired electron exhibits a high degree of freedom, and thus the spin is not split by the I = 1/2 nucleus of silver. This also suggests that SAAg should not form Ag-Ag bonds with the surfaces of AgCl or AgNPs. Hence, we propose that SAAg is stabilized by Cl− ions on the surfaces of AgCl particles of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 (see the optional rational structures SAAg in Fig. 7). As such, SAAg could contact the AgX surfaces intimately with little Schottky barrier.

Recently, Tang, Zou, Wang and others have loaded atomically dispersed silver on various supports by calcination of the Ag+-containing precursors (Table S2) [49–51]. The notable differences in the present work are: (1) a solvothermal method is applied, (2) the oxidation state of SAAg is 0, versus + 1 in the previous studies, (3) the loading of SAAg is only 6.0 × 10–8 mol g−1, versus over 10–4 mol g−1 of Ag ions, and (4) SAAg is essential for the emergence of the deiodination activity, versus the improved catalytic activities relative to AgNPs due to the enhanced atomic efficiency and the well-controlled coordination environment.

The incident photons absorbed by AgNPs induces the generation of hot electrons and holes. Subsequently, the hot electrons migrate to the CB of AgCl [42,65]. This charge separation process has been examined by numerous studies on the plasmonic Ag(0)-AgX photocatalysts [42,65–67]. For example, Hu et al. used an electrochemical method to corroborate the electron migration from photo-irradiated AgNPs to AgI and then to molecular O2 during the photocatalytic oxidative degradation of 4-chlorophenol in water under aerobic conditions [42,67]. Back electron transfer from CB of AgCl to AgNPs encounters a large Schottky barrier (0.8 eV) and is kinetically prohibited [40]. As a result, AgNPs becomes electron-deficient and in such scenario reduction reactions do not occur at the AgNPs’ surfaces of the Ag(0)-AgX hybrids. Rather, the reduction of the organic halides can only occur by the electrons accumulated in CB of AgCl with the assistance of SAAg. The above mechanism well explains why SAAg serves as the active site at which the reductive deiodination takes place.

Scheme 2 depicts three possible elementary reactions with the working state of SAAg by which 1 is 1e–-reduced to paramethoxyphenyl radical (PMP·). Reaction 1 would lead to the oxidative quenching of SAAg and fixation of the iodide atom in the resultant AgI. This path can be excluded based on the following results: (1) SAAg of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 did not decay during the photocatalytic reaction (Figs. S11), (2) ca. 60% iodide atoms of 1 were released into the bulk solution and (3) photo-excitation of AgEG/Mg(OH)2 is essential for the conversion of 1 (no dark reaction occurred at 80 °C; see Table S1). Reaction 2 is analogous to the charge distribution between UV-irradiated TiO2 and gold NPs [68–70]. For reaction 2, an electron in CB of AgCl is injected into the half-filled 5s orbital of SAAg in prior to the reduction reaction. This will generate Ag− which is highly reducing due to its small electron binding energy (1.30 eV in gas phase [71]) and bring about a large energy of repulsion between Ag− and the neighboring Cl− ions. However, since both processes are thermodynamically unfavoured, reaction 2 is also considered very unlikely.

Only reaction 3 fully rationalizes the role of SAAg, in which the electron injection and the reduction of 1 are concerted and thus the oxidation state of SAAg maintains during the reduction reaction. This role of SAAg is consistent with the remarkable electrocatalytic activities of metallic Ag(0) cathodes in reduction of organic halides [47,48,72–75] and the high affinity of Ag(0) surfaces to both the substrates and the radical intermediates [76–78]. Importantly, since the high dispersity of SAAg should maximize the interfacial interaction of Ag(0) with both C-I bond and the radical intermediate, this reaction route suggests enhanced reductive dehalogenation activity of other catalysts may also be realized by using SAAg instead of bulk Ag(0) or AgNPs.

By converting a small portion of the Ag+ ions on the surfaces of AgCl grains into SAAg upon a solvothermal method, an advanced plasmonic AgEG/Mg(OH)2 photocatalyst has been fabricated. The quantity of SAAg is very small 6.0 × 10–8 mol g−1. While SAAg do not much enhance the sunlight absorption efficiency or activities of oxidative degradations, it plays the key role in the reductive borylation of organic iodides under visible light irradiation with a large TOF of 1.4 × 104 h−1. Moreover, the current system could selectively convert aryl iodides to the corresponding organic boronates or hydrodehalogenation products. The activities and the selectivities are excellent. AgEG/Mg(OH)2 is competent for a broad scope of aryl iodides and common boron sources. This work is a good example showing that upgrading catalytically active components from nanoparticles to single atoms, namely, AgNPs to SAAg, endows atomically dispersed catalysts with catalytic capability that conventional nanocatalysts do not possess [64]. Therefore, this study not only develops a visible light-driven heterogeneous photocatalyst for selective dehalogenation, but also may open a door of using single atoms for design of novel (photo-) catalysts with improved dehalogenation capabilities.
